title: Chapter 13: Department of Engineering
summary: The article provides course descriptions for the School of Engineering at Santa Clara University. One course, ENGR 334: Energy, Climate Change, and Social Justice, focuses on the ethical issues surrounding energy use and climate change within the framework of social justice. The article also briefly mentions ENGR 336: Engineering for the Developing World, which teaches students how to design and manage products and services for developing markets and ENGR 338: Mobile Applications for Emerging Markets which provides an overview of technological innovation and its impact in those markets.

title: Chapter 12: Department of Engineering
summary: This article introduces a list of environmental and business-related graduate courses offered at Santa Clara University.   These courses cover topics such as green innovation, entrepreneurship, bioengineering, energy conservation and sustainability, and engineering ethics.  The courses are designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills needed to address the environmental and social challenges of the 21st century.

title: India Microgrid (CHP, Natural Gas, Solar PV, Diesel, Fuel Cell, Remote, Grid Connected, Hybrid) Market Size, Share & Trends Analysis Report 2024-2030
summary: The Indian microgrid market is projected to reach USD 8.01 billion by 2030, driven by factors such as increasing demand for reliable power supply, especially in remote areas, government initiatives promoting renewable energy, and technological advancements. The market is expected to grow in various segments including power source, connection type, and end-use, due to the need for sustainable and resilient energy solutions. Key players in the market include companies such as NTPC Ltd., Eaton Corporation Plc, and Schneider Electric SE.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article describes the use of microgrids as a sustainable energy solution, which meets the criteria for green innovation because it contributes to environmental sustainability goals such as decarbonisation and reducing resource consumption.

green_product: TRUE. Microgrids can be considered a green product because they are designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces their environmental impact throughout their life cycle, including the use of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency.
green_process: TRUE. Microgrids can be considered a green process because they minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability by using renewable energy sources, reducing waste, conserving natural resources, and decreasing energy consumption.
